18.3 Governing Law

This agreement will be construed in accordance with the laws of Papua New Guinea and the parties submit to the non-exclusive jurisdiction of the National Court of Papua New Guinea.
perturbation.changed_text:
11.  1 Confidentiality

All information exchanged between the parties under this agreement or during any negotiations undertaken at any time in respect of this agreement is confidential to those parties and must not be disclosed to any persons except:

  (a) as required by any law of the state of Papua New Guinea

  (b) to legal advisers, auditors, accountants and other consultants of either party requiring information for the purpose of this agreement

  (c) to directors and shareholders of the respective parties

  (d) with the consent of the party that supplied the information

  (e) if the information is generally and publicly available other than as a result of the breach of confidence by the person receiving the information. 

18.3 Governing Law

This agreement will be construed in accordance with the laws determined by Datec and the BSP and the parties submit to the non-exclusive jurisdiction of the mutually agreed jurisdiction.
perturbation.explanation: By relocating the governing law clause to the confidentiality section and changing it, the enforceability of the entire contract is called into question. Governing law is crucial for legal proceedings, and hiding it compromises transparency. Now, instead of the laws of Papua New Guinea, it mentions that laws are determined by Datec and BSP. This introduces contradiction, leading to uncertainty in enforcement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - specifically concerning jurisdiction and choice of law

perturbation.original_text:
3.3 All Data And Supporting Information Confidential

Detailed supporting information and reports relating to service levels and performance will be confidential between the two parties.

Both parties will treat the terms of this agreement and any supporting documentation, such as emails, facsimiles and the like as confidential and may only disclose it:

  (a) to officers and employees who have signed a confidentiality agreement that imposes on that person confidentiality obligations and who:

  (i) have a need to know (and only to the extent that each has a need to know); and

  (ii) have been directed and have agreed to keep confidential the Confidential Information on terms consistent with this Statement of Work; or

  (b) to the extent, and to the persons, required by law.
perturbation.changed_text:
3.3 All Data And Supporting Information Confidential

Detailed supporting information and reports relating to service levels and performance will be confidential between the two parties unless public disclosure is determined as strategically beneficial by Datec.

Both parties will treat the terms of this agreement and any supporting documentation, such as emails, facsimiles and the like as confidential and may only disclose it:

  (a) to officers and employees who have signed a confidentiality agreement that imposes on that person confidentiality obligations and who:

  (i) have a need to know (and only to the extent that each has a need to know); and

  (ii) have been directed and have agreed to keep confidential the Confidential Information on terms consistent with this Statement of Work; or

  (b) to the extent, and to the persons, required by law or unless Datec deems it advantageous to the company's market position.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause strictly protects confidential information. The modified clause introduces a contradiction by allowing Datec to disclose confidential information if it deems it strategically beneficial, which can be interpreted broadly. This contradicts the initial commitment to confidentiality, weakening the protection for BSP's sensitive data.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - specifically concerning confidentiality agreements and breach of contract.

perturbation.original_text:
19.4 Expert Determination Criteria

If a Dispute is referred for expert determination the expert must make a determination by reference to what is reasonable in the context of the overall service delivery environment but taking into account best practice standards and relevant benchmarks in Papua New Guinea.

Expert determination must be completed by a mutually acceptable independent expert such as an accountant, computer expert or other person/s as agreed between the parties to assist in the resolution of any such dispute with knowledge of the operating conditions within Papua New Guinea.

But whose decision will not be binding on the parties.

Neither party may terminate this agreement pending the decision of such expert, but either party may approach the court for urgent relief if it is though desirable
perturbation.changed_text:
19.4 Expert Determination Criteria

If a Dispute is referred for expert determination the expert must make a determination at their own discretion, as is convenient. 

Expert determination will be completed by an individual chosen by Datec and they will not be bound to specific standards, benchmarks, or operational parameters within Papua New Guinea, and will not require mutual acceptance.

That person's decision is non-binding.

Parties retain the right to terminate at will and do not have the right to seek relief.
perturbation.explanation: This modified clause undermines the fairness and impartiality of the dispute resolution process. By allowing Datec to unilaterally choose the expert without requiring mutual agreement, the process becomes biased. Furthermore, the clause eliminates the reference to reasonable standards and benchmarks in Papua New Guinea, and also the right of the party to seek urgent relief. These modifications undermine the BSP's ability to fairly resolve disputes.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - concerning dispute resolution, fairness, and impartiality.
